results.title: Goodness - it's milk!
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit
results.brief_description:
This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, promotes the dairy industry by proclaiming the benefits of drinking milk.

The film opens with some lovely footage of a couple exploring the Blue Dandenongs, including a milkbar with signs for ‘Peter’s Ice-Cream’, ‘Herald’, and ‘Four ‘n’ Twenty Pies’, where they order two tall glasses of milk.

The film then shows scenes of schoolchildren, a patient and nurse in a hospital and a domestic kitchen, while the narrator describes the health benefits of milk. The film finishes with footage of the dairy industry, from the farm to industrial pasteurising and bottling processes, and finally home delivery.

results.title: Going Our Way
results.creator_credit: Chris Gallagher, Victorian Railways and Crawford Productions
results.brief_description: Presents the many employment opportunities in the Victorian Railways. A young boy playing with his toys, including a train, dreams of his future. He becomes a station assistant. Shows how he learns his job and benefits from the V.R.I. library and sporting clubs. Includes executive officers who started at the bottom and worked their way to the top.

results.title: Gippsland Honeymoon
results.brief_description:
A honeymoon couple tour the Gippsland area and admire the scenic attractions of the country-side. Depicts many of Victoria’s famous tourist attractions including: Lakes Entrance, Gippsland, Orbost, the Snowy River, the Tambo River, Bairnsdale, Omeo, Walhalla Goldfields, Buchan Caves, Mallacoota Inlet, La Trobe Valley, Glen Maggie Weir and Ninety Mile Beach. Produced in conjunction with The Tourist Development Authority and The Gippsland Lakes and Tourist Promotion Council.

This film was discussed on ABC Gippsland Radio on 14 March 2020. The following are comments for viewers which add insight into the film

Martin Richardson “Joe” is Joe Southon, from Paynesville who wasn’t actually a Lakes Entrance fisherman, but was the chosen “talent” for the movie - it was through his connections that the film crew came down here to make the movie. He was a farmer, part-time fisherman, and farm manager whose property occupied a large part of what is now the town of Paynesville. He was also involved in many civic roles around the Bairnsdale Shire. His daughter Beryl and son Bluey still live in Paynesville.

Ashley Meek My father features on this add fishing at the Glenmaggie spillway

Neil Walters who picked up one of the narrators was Ross Higgins. “put the money on the fridge wog.!” (Kingswood Country)

Graeme Nixon Cape Conran my dad jim nixon boat and me. Front boat

results.title: Get out and live
results.creator_credit: Col Lewis and Cameracraft Film Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1972 film, produced for the Main Roads Department, Brisbane, describes the establishment of an emergency control organisation within the department, and shows the training and implementation of an emergency evacuation of 1,500 people from the 14 storey office building.

Produced by Cameracraft Film Productions.

The colour is faded throughout the film and there are jumps in the soundtrack throughout due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Gateway to a city [West Gate Bridge]
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description: Melbourne’s West Gate Bridge is a gateway to the future - a future of unprecedented residential, commercial and industrial growth for Melbourne and its Western regions. This film of the opening ceremony gives a historical outlook to the development of the river, shipping and the effects on the growth of the city of Melbourne.

results.title: Early Melbourne mansions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “National Trust”.
Looks at three Melbourne mansions, Toorak House, Trewalla and Illawarra, including brief histories.

results.title: Fremantle cray fishers
results.brief_description: The departure of the cray fishing boats from Fremantle, Western Australia, in the early morning to the fishing grounds in the deep water. These hard working fishermen work a twelve hour day and are dependent on the weather and the mood of the sea for a good season. After the long day they return to port with their catch.

results.title: Echoes in Freestone
results.creator_credit: Ray Barnes, John M. Bale and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description: Using sounds from the past, over pictures of the present, the film glimpses a man’s life in pioneering days. Set in the historic town of Richmond, Tasmania, the film shows some of the classic colonial Georgian houses and churches, many of which date from the early days.

results.title: Easy does it
results.creator_credit: Anthony Gibb, Don Anderson, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1967 film is a light-hearted look at the correct methods of manual handling in order to avoid back strain and injury. The film shows footage of factory and manual labourers handling various heavy loads, including using equipment to aid safe lifting. This footage is interspersed with examples of everyday strain such as women hanging out the washing and lifting a baby from a pram; and moments of slapstick comedy as a man struggles to carry his bride over the threshold of their house and a man lifts a keg of beer at a barbeque.

Produced by Tasfilm Productions for the Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.
